sub_title: PhD Candidate at Princeton University; Visiting Research Fellow Rubenianum
summary:
Experienced researcher, with a history of working in the museum world and higher education. Skilled in curating, writing for various audiences, and teaching. Scheduled to complete a Doctor of Philosophy in Art & Archaeology from Princeton University in spring 2024. 

My work centers on early modern art and architecture. My current project focuses on the Hanse -a pan-European organization of merchants and cities- and the way its members employed art to build their polity. Investigating drawings, engravings, maps, paintings, and architecture, commissioned by a group of influential Hanse merchant-diplomats in the sixteenth and early seventeenth century, help us to discern the self-perception of the merchants and how they positioned themselves and their organization in an increasingly globalizing world. Ultimately, I plea for an art history of institutions. Before starting the PhD program in Princeton, Suzie worked in contemporary art as curator of exhibitions and public programs.

I am keen on communicating stories yet untold, but that remain crucial for our understanding present-day societal, political, religious, and economic issues. 

My research interests include: early modern art and architecture (1400-1800), relation between image and text, urban history, politics, trade, global art history, art collecting and patronage studies, historiography, cartography, artistic networks, and the history of institutions.

awards.title: Explokart Fellowship
awards.description: Explokart fellowships are granted yearly to scholars who study the history of cartography and explore the rich map collections in Amsterdam and beyond, in close collaboration with the Explokart chair of historical cartography at the University of Amsterdam and Allard Pierson.

awards.title: Bursary
awards.description:
Conducting research on the notion of the Renaissance and the relations between Italy and Hungary in the 15th - 16th century at the Hungarian Academy, The American Academy, The Austrian Academy, the British Academy and the Vatican Secret Archives. Preparing an article on the position of the patronage of Cardinal Tamás Bakócz (1442-1521) in historiography and viewing Bakócz' life, work, and art commissions from a pan-European perspective. 

Key words: Renaissance studies; Relations Italy and Hungary; cardinals; patronage studies; Art and architecture; Geography of art; Art and politics.
awards.issuer: KNIR - The Royal Netherlands Institute in Rome

awards.title: Honors Program Degree; Art, Practice and Research
awards.description:
The Honours Programme ART and RESEARCH consists of a collaboration between the Gerrit Rietveld Academie and the University of Amsterdam. Developed in 2006, it aims to combine the best of both institutions in a program that allows art students the opportunity to engage with theory on a deeper level than what is offered in the Gerrit Rietveld Academie’s regular courses, while on the other hand, it involves university students in creative processes absent in the scope of the University of Amsterdam’s courses. Departing from the idea that there are certain overlaps between the practices of science and art, it provides students with the incentive to link different perspectives and methodologies, as well as challenge traditions, in order to create and develop new modes of research, while learning from each other’s fields of study in the process.

http://www.artandresearch.nl/
awards.issuer: Gerrit Rietveld Academy, University of Amsterdam

projects.title: Hansards in the World. Continuity and Discontinuity on the Intellectual, Cultural, and Economic Frontiers of the Early Modern Hanse.
projects.description:
On 12 & 13 May 2022, the international and interdisciplinary symposium Hansards in the World took place in Amsterdam. The symposium gathered and promoted new histories of how the merchants, diplomats, intellectuals, politicians, and craftspeople associated with the Hanse interacted with the wider world in the early modern period. Contributions explored novel perspectives on and approaches to the late life and afterlife of the Hanse. Our participants consider how our view of the Hanse, its people, and its encounters with the non-Hanseatic world changes if we focus on art, everyday life, or political and intellectual currents in the period of its supposed decline from the sixteenth century onwards.

The symposium was a collaboration between Princeton University's Department of Art & Archaeology and the Amsterdam School for Historical Studies of the University of Amsterdam.

contributors.headline: PhD Candidate at Princeton University; Visiting Research Fellow Rubenianum

projects.title: Has Anything Changed? New Strategies and Adaptive Methodologies in Art History Since COVID-19
projects.description:
The symposium centered on the theme of the effects of COVID-19 on scholarship in the humanities. Graduate Students and distinguished guest speakers investigated how people and institutions adapt to changing global circumstances, not only in the economic and political sphere, but in art, culture, and society. The Symposium showcased reflections on the various transformations that took place in the past few years, which unfolded in a series of workshops and round table conversations.

The organizers of the symposium set out to inquire and analyze the ways that the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a dividing line between what we call a “pre-” and “post-” moment. The unprecedented transformation calls for a re-evaluation of established methods, and demands scholars to forge new paths and strategies toward research, theory, and critical engagement of art history and the humanities. As art historians, we used to assume that looking at an object must take place in real space and time, within the three-dimensional spaces of our world. Today, such encounters are more ambivalent, as they are being increasingly facilitated within virtual or augmented settings, affecting the way we look at and think about objects. We asked, in what ways have conventional art historical narratives and methodologies been disrupted or destabilized? How has our discipline transformed or adapted to recent events? How have arts education and pedagogy been impacted by the shift toward the digital? And consequently, what is the future of art history? How can art history incorporate and engage with these new ways of “looking,” both sensorial and conceptual? To address this question, it is imperative that we reconsider access to objects, archives, and sites. This, in turn, leads us to grapple with theoretical frameworks and new realities and conditions, from political reckonings to racial justice to ever more marked financial disparities.

contributors.headline: PhD Candidate at Princeton University; Visiting Research Fellow Rubenianum
PhD Candidate, Department of Art & Archaeology, Princeton University

projects.title: Mobility and Cosmopolitanism: Books, Art, and Patronage
projects.description:
Dr. Deborah Hutton (The College of New Jersey) and Dr. Emily Mann (Courtauld Institute of Art), shared reflections on their research and embark on methodological explorations guided by questions such as: how did art, architecture, and books shape the increasingly globalizing world in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries; how do spatio-temporal concepts such as "Early Modern Europe" relate to time in South Asia; how does the location of objects affect meaning when in transit, by change of ownership, or permanency on one location?

This event is a culmination of the collaboration between Andrew W. Mellon fellows at the Rijksmuseum Namrata B. Kanchan and Suzie Hermán and their investigations into the intersections of their research projects on, respectively, Royal Albums from the Deccan and The Art World of the Hanse.

projects.title: Mirrors of Romania
projects.description: Mirrors of Romania is a foundation, founded in 2014. It's main objective is to show the arts from Romania in the Netherlands and stimulate artistic exchange. It aims at collecting, producing and sharing knowledge on the arts in Romania. Currently MoR works at realizing an international arts exhibition and exchange to be held in Romania and in the Netherlands, showing current state of the arts in reflection of 25 years of democracy in Romania. This project will exhibit art and connect artists of various generations, disciplines and languages from Romania and the Netherlands.

profile_positions.description: The Vereniging van Nederlandse Kunsthistorici (VNK) or Association of Dutch Art Historians was founded in 1939 and currently has (ca.) 850 members. The VNK is committed to advocating for historians of art and architecture in the Netherlands and promoting the professional practice of art history. I am serving on the board to advance and support art historical research. Within this framework I coordinate the awarding of two prizes for excellent scholarship. The Karel van Mander Prize is awarded to an author for an outstanding art historical publication -each year in a different sub-category- that appeared in the past five years. The Jan van Gelder Prize grants support to an art historian under 35 for an outstanding doctoral dissertation.
profile_positions.title: Board Member

profile_positions.description: As academic affairs officer I served the Graduate Student Government advocating for graduate students with a focus on international students. I worked closely together with representatives of various resources on campus such as the McGraw Center for Teaching and Learning, Professional Development, and the Graduate School.

profile_positions.title: Curator, Co-founder

profile_positions.description:
Since 2013 I worked project-based with Jonas Staal and his studio team and from 2015 I became a full-time member of the studio. In this capacity I conducted research, produced exhibitions, and was responsible for PR and communications.

About Jonas Staal.
Staal is a visual artist whose work deals with the relation between art, propaganda, and democracy. He is the founder of the artistic and political organization New World Summit (2012–ongoing). Together with Florian Malzacher he co-directs the training camp Training for the Future (2018-ongoing), and with human rights lawyer Jan Fermon he initiated the collective action lawsuit Collectivize Facebook (2020-ongoing). With writer and lawyer Radha D’Souza he founded the Court for Intergenerational Climate Crimes (2021-ongoing) and with Laure Prouvost he is co-administrator of the Obscure Union.

Exhibition-projects include Art of the Stateless State (Moderna Galerija, Ljubljana, 2015), The Scottish-European Parliament (CCA, Glasgow, 2018), Museum as Parliament (with the Democratic Self-Administration of Rojava, Van Abbemuseum, Eindhoven, 2018-ongoing) and We Demand a Million More Years (Fondazione Sandretto Re Rebaudengo, Turin, 2022). His projects have been exhibited widely at venues such as the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam, M_HKA in Antwerp, Moderna Museet in Stockholm, Centre Pompidou-Metz and the Nam June Paik Art Center in Seoul, as well as the 7th Berlin Biennale, the 31st São Paulo Biennale and the 12th Taipei Biennale.

Staal completed his PhD research on propaganda art at the PhDArts program of Leiden University, the Netherlands.
